values.comments:
Do people exhibit true concern for the welfare of others, without the promise of personal gain? Is economics lacking because it treats people as purely self-motivated? Can insight from psychology help to fill the void? Co-taught by members of both the economics and psychology departments, this seminar discusses whether fairness perceptions clash with economic principles. The discussion relies heavily on experimental and empirical evidence. Based on the interests of participants, topics may include attitudes about wealth redistribution, the tradeoff between equality and efficiency, claims that goods such as the environment are \"incommensurable,\" repugnance in markets, fairness as a constraint on profits, and anti-market bias.

Students, for the most part, were happy with the course content. One wrote, “I really liked the format, I wouldn\'t change anything for next year. [There was an] [a]ppropriate amount of work and great discussion.” Another said, “[r]eadings and class discussions were very interesting and engaging. A few complained that “[s]ome weeks… the readings did not seem at all related and so it was hard to have a focused discussion on a particular topic,” while others wrote that the “readings become repetitive rather quickly.” The quality of the readings and amount learned from the course were still fairly high.

Students found that Professor Dana was “excellent and enjoyable to have class with.” They also enjoyed the co-teaching format. One declared that “Professor Jason Dana and Professor David Dillenberger have been among the best professors I have ever had.”

The amount of work in the class was relatively low. Work outside of class consisted solely of readings and one final paper. Regarding the final paper, one student wrote that “the kind of final paper we are writing is something that not many students in the class are used to,” but added that “both instructors have been great about discussing ideas and helping.” This course was strongly recommended to majors.
